TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested by police officers on suspicion of being a member of an illegal organisation , namely PERSON ( NORP Left ) and was taken into custody .
CARDINAL . On DATE an investigating judge remanded the applicant in custody in FAC .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor at ORG filed a bill of indictment against the applicant and CARDINAL other co - accused , charging them with membership of an illegal , armed organisation and participation in activities that undermined the constitutional order of the ORG . The public prosecutor sought the death penalty for the applicant , pursuant to LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was released pending trial .

CARDINAL . Following a constitutional amendment in DATE , ORG were abolished and the applicant 's case was transferred to ORG . On CARDINAL DATE ORG convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced him to life imprisonment . ORG quashed this judgment . The case was remitted to ORG , where it is apparently still pending .
CARDINAL . The applicant was detained in FAC . He had various health problems and underwent several operations . He has submitted medical reports to this effect .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was transferred to the ORG / PERSON . On his arrival at the prison , the security forces and the prison guards allegedly subjected the applicant to a strip- search , which included an anal inspection . The applicant complained about this incident to the ORG public prosecutor .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the applicant was to be taken to hospital for a routine medical check when he was again allegedly subjected , by force , to an anal and oral inspection . The applicant tried to resist the search , which he thought was degrading . Following this , the security forces drew up a report , stating that the applicant had objected to the search and had therefore not been taken to hospital . The applicant filed a complaint with the ORG public prosecutor about this treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's lawyer complained to ORG and Prisons regarding the incident of DATE . She submitted that her client had been subjected to a degrading search and had not been taken to hospital for a medical examination . She requested that the applicant be transferred to FAC in GPE in order to facilitate his treatment and to avoid the problems related to transfers and searches .

CARDINAL . In a letter dated DATE , the ORG disputed the content of that complaint . They maintained that the applicant had received medical treatment in the infirmary of the ORG / Kocaeli F Type Prison , as well as having been taken to ORG on DATE . They added that the prison authorities were corresponding with a hospital in GPE in order to arrange for the applicant 's subsequent medical treatment . Lastly , they maintained that a prison change was unnecessary as the applicant could be conveyed to and from the hospital in GPE if necessary .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's lawyer filed a complaint with ORG . She stated that her client had been subjected to degrading treatment during a search on DATE , and had been detained in solitary confinement because of his resistance to that measure . She asked the court to take the necessary action against the prison officers concerned . She also requested that her client be transferred back to the cell which he had shared with CARDINAL other inmates , or to another one which would allow him to mix with others in the courtyard .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected this request . It concluded that ORG ( PERSON ) had placed the applicant in a room where he could share part of the prison courtyard with CARDINAL other inmates . The complaint concerning the acts of the prison officers was left for the public prosecutor to consider .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor decided that no prosecution should be brought against the prison guards of the ORG / PERSON in respect of the events of DATE . In his decision not to prosecute , the prosecutor noted that the security forces had been obliged to use force to restrain the prisoners ( including the applicant ) since they had resisted transfer from FAC to FAC . After their arrival at FAC , the prisoners had been examined by a doctor who had drawn up medical reports . He concluded that there was thus no concrete evidence to prosecute the soldiers or the prison guards .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's lawyer challenged the public prosecutor 's decision of DATE before ORG . She maintained that the public prosecutor had decided not to prosecute without having conducted a sufficient preliminary investigation . She argued that , under domestic law , it was compulsory for a public prosecutor to commence criminal proceedings where there was enough testimony to show that the security forces and the prison officers could have been responsible for the alleged ill - treatment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was transferred to ORG . He was released from that prison on DATE .

CARDINAL . In a letter dated DATE , the governor of the ORG / PERSON informed the PERSON public prosecutor that the applicant had been held in a single room DATE and DATE , though not by way of disciplinary punishment . He maintained that the applicant could share the courtyard with other inmates . He relied on the report prepared by the psychological and social services , which had recommended that the applicant be sent to another prison as he had fallen out with his friends from the organisation and therefore had no one to share the room with . The applicant maintained that the “ single room ” mentioned in the letter was a cell from where he could not share the courtyard with other inmates .
